question: Question_04
statement:
A rectangular storage container with an open top is to have volume of 8
cubic metres. The length of its base is twice the width. Material for
the base costs \$4.50 per square metre, and material for the sides costs
\$6 per square metre. Find the cost of the material for the cheapest
such container.
sols:
We wish to \emph{minimize} the \textbf{cost}, C, subject to the
constraint that the volume of the container must be
$V = 8 \text{m}^{3}$. The cost C can be expressed as the sum of the
costs for all the sides. Recall that this is an open-top box (i.e., no
top). If we let \emph{l}, \emph{w}, and \emph{h} denote the length,
width, and height of the box in metres, respectively, then:

\begin{align*}
C &= C_{\text{sides}} + C_{\text{bottom}} \\
&= 6 (2hw + 2hl) + 4.5(lw)\end{align*}

since material for the base costs \$4.50 per square metre, and material
for the sides costs \$6 per square metre.

We are also given the constraint

\begin{align*}\displaystyle V = lwh = 8\end{align*} Using the fact that the length is twice
the width (i.e., \emph{l = 2w}), the cost function and volume constraint
are expressed as

\begin{align*}\displaystyle C = 36hw + 9w^{2}, \quad V = 2w^{2}h = 8\end{align*}

To reduce this into a single variable problem, we use the constraint to
express the \emph{height} of the box \emph{in terms of the width}:

\begin{align*}h = \frac{4}{w^{2}},\end{align*} and substitute this into the cost function
\emph{C}, making it a function of \emph{w} only:

\begin{align*}C(w) = \frac{144}{w} + 9w^{2}\end{align*}

To optimize C, we determine first determine its critical points by
differentiating with respect to \emph{w} and setting the derivative
equal to zero:

\begin{align*}
C'(w) &= -\frac{144}{w^{2}} + 18w \\
0 &= -\frac{144}{w^{2}} + 18w \\
144 &= 18w^3 \\
8 &= w^3 \\
w &= 2\end{align*}

Therefore \emph{w} = 2 is a critical point. To determine whether or not
it is the point that minimizes \emph{C}, we use the \textbf{second
derivative test}. The second derivative of C with respect to w is

\begin{align*}C''(w) = \frac{288}{w^{3}} + 18\end{align*} which is clearly greater than zero
when \emph{w} = 2. Thus, by the second derivative test, \emph{C} has a
local minimum at \emph{w} = 2 (Moreover, it is the \emph{global minimum}
since there are no other critical points.) Substituting \emph{w} = 2
into the cost function, we determine that the minimum cost is

\begin{align*}C(2) = \frac{144}{2} + 9(2)^{2} = 72 + 36 = {\color{blue}$108}\end{align*}
